snippet: A day after American commandos carried out raids in two African countries, Libya’s interim government demanded an explanation from Washington for what it called the “kidnapping” of a Libyan suspect.
abstract: Libya's fragile interim government condemns the United States for raids that led to capture of terror suspect Nazih Abdul-Hamed al-Ruqai, as lawmakers threaten to remove prime minister if government turns out to have been involved; United States' decision to undertake mission indicates that it has given up waiting for Libyan government to grow strong enough to challenge powerful militias.

byline.original: By CARLOTTA GALL and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
byline.contributor: Carlotta Gall reported from Tripoli, Libya, and David D. Kirkpatrick from Cairo. Reporting was contributed by Eric Schmitt from San Francisco, Mark Mazzetti from Madrid, and Suliman Ali Zway and Osama Alfitory from Tripoli.

lead_paragraph: A day after American commandos carried out raids in two African countries, Libya’s interim government demanded an explanation from Washington for what it called the “kidnapping” of a Libyan suspect.

headline.main: Libya Condemns U.S. for Seizing Terror Suspect
headline.print_headline: Libya condemns U.S. for Seizing Terror Suspect

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
